descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: After Shawn Marion scored 16 of his 21 points in the first half, Seattle's Brent Barry scored 14 of his 25 in the second half as the SuperSonics pulled away for an 86-73 victory over the Suns.
article.headline: Barry shoots Sonics past Suns with 25 points
article.linkText: Barry shoots Sonics past Suns with 25 points
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- Message from Brent Barry to the rest of the NBA: Watch out!
Barry

Barry had eight of his 25 points in the fourth quarter and Gary Payton scored 20 as the Seattle SuperSonics opened their season with an 86-73 victory over the Phoenix Suns on Wednesday night. Afterward, Barry jokingly put out the word that his eighth season will be special. "I'm such an offensive weapon,'' he said, trying to suppress a wry smile. "We run every play through me. Nobody can shut me down.'' He was kidding, of course, even though his play last season should have been a signal that he would be a leader on a young Seattle squad. Barry averaged 14.4 points, 5.4 rebounds and 3.3 assists in 2001-02. "The aggressive play he showed, especially in the second half, is something that he's capable of, and we're going to need him to do that on a consistent basis this season,'' Sonics coach Nate McMillan said. Barry scored six points during a 12-2 run midway through the fourth, helping the Sonics build a 78-66 lead with 5:13 remaining when he scored a backdoor layup on a nice feed from Payton. Barry shot 9-of-12, including 5-of-6 from 3-point range. "I've been working hard after practice, getting my shot and my stroke together, to start off the season shooting the ball well,'' he said. Desmond Mason scored 11 and Rashard Lewis had 10 for Seattle. "We all know what type of player Brent is,'' Lewis said. "Tonight he stepped it up another notch. We feel on any given night, it could be any one of us. It could be me, it could be Desmond. Each night we're going to need it from somebody.'' The Suns cut it to 79-73 with 1:56 to play on a basket by Penny Hardaway, but Payton hit a 3-pointer and Vladimir Radmanovic added the final four points as the Sonics put the game out of reach. Shawn Marion had 21 points and 11 rebounds to lead the Suns, who lost their opener for the fourth straight year. "We weren't doing the things in the second half that we did in the first half to get the lead,'' Marion said. "Barry had a good game. Coach said not to leave him open. He can shoot the ball. We left him open and he made shots.'' Hardaway added 16, starting in place of Stephon Marbury, who was suspended for one game by the NBA after his summer drunken driving conviction. Phoenix's Amare Stoudamire, the only rookie drafted out of high school this season, had 10 points and six rebounds in his NBA debut. "It's a learning process,'' Stoudamire said. "I'll just come out the next game with a different type of mentality. I made a lot of mistakes out there. I'm looking forward to practice tomorrow.'' Barry was everywhere the Sonics needed him during the fourth quarter. He hit a 3-pointer early in the period for a 64-60 lead, then tipped in a miss by Payton and fed Ansu Sesay for an easy basket that put Seattle ahead 70-64. On the next Phoenix possession, Barry came through again, stealing the ball from Johnson and racing downcourt. He drew the foul on Johnson and hit both free throws to give the Sonics a 72-64 lead with 7:46 to play. Barry hit three of his 3-pointers in the first half, keeping the Sonics within 42-39 at the break despite their 43 percent shooting. "I took advantage of some guys doubling down on Gary,'' Barry said. "When we swing the ball, those shots open up. You just have to be in rhythm and ready to shoot.''

Game notes
Rookie Reggie Evans, the only undrafted free agent to make Seattle's roster, started but went scoreless without taking a shot. ... former Sonics stars Spencer Haywood, Michael Cage, Jack Sikma, Tom Chambers, Xavier McDaniel, John Johnson and Slick Watts were honored during introductions. ... F Vitaly Potapenko (left knee) is on the injured list and G Kenny Anderson (back spasms) didn't suit up for Seattle. ... Under new rules, officials reviewed a basket by Marion at the end of the first half. It counted, giving the Suns a 49-39 lead. ... Phoenix last won an opener in 1998-99, beating the L.A. Clippers 101-92.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
